maxGrade.name: maxGrade
maxGrade.comment: Indicates what is the highest grade that can be set in this category.

minGrade.name: minGrade
minGrade.comment: Indicates what is the lowest grade that can be set in this category.

constructors.comment:
Creates a new geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder object.

See GeekCodeCategoryBuilder.GeekCodeCategoryBuilder for a description of the parameters.

A.name: A
A.comment: Sets the "type" variable for this category to geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixType.A.

B.comment: Sets the "type" variable for this category to geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixType.B.

C.comment: Sets the "type" variable for this category to geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixType.C.

I.comment: Sets the "type" variable for this category to geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixType.I.

subValidate.name: subValidate
subValidate.comment:
Lets any implementations of this class execute more specific validations to make sure the builder is set correctly.

This method is invoked from GeekCodeCategory.grade and shouldn't be invoked directly.

Returns a geek_code/geek_code-v312.GeekCodeCategory (or extension of it) if all validations are successful.

geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.subValidate.grade is the grade to apply to this category.

type.name: type
type.comment:
Sets the "type" variable for this category using geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.type.type.

geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.B, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.L, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.U, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.A, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.V, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.H, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.I, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.O, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.S, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.C, geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.X and geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.other are all respective shortcuts for this method.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart:core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

crossover.name: crossover
crossover.comment:
geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.crossover.crossover will be used a crossover for this category.

Original documentation:

()
 For indicating "cross-overs" or ranges. Geeks who go from C+ to C--- depending on the situation (i.e. mostly "C+") could use C+(---). @ is different from () in that () has finite limits within the category, while @ ranges all over.

grade.name: grade
grade.comment:
Validates all the build parameters and builds the geek_code/geek_code-v312.GeekCodeCategory with geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.grade.grade and returns it.

Validation is composed of these steps:

  • Ensuring the code provided in the constructor is not null and that its length is not 0

  • Ensuring the minumum and maximum grades provided in the constructor are not null

  • Ensuring the minimum grade is smaller than the maximum grade

  • Ensuring that geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.grade.grade is not null and falls within the bounds set by geek_code/geek_code.GeekCodeCategoryBuilder.minGrade and geek_code/geek_code.GeekCodeCategoryBuilder.maxGrade

If any of these validations fail a geek_code/geek_code-v312.GeekCodeError will get thrown.

Once those steps complete successfully geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.subValidate is called with geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.grade.grade and returned.

living.name: living
living.comment:
Original documentation:

$
 Indicates that this particular category is done for a living. For example, UL+++$ indicates that the person utilizes Unix and gets paid for it. Quite a lucky geek, for sure.

noKnowledge.name: noKnowledge
noKnowledge.comment:
Original documentation:

?
 Unless stated otherwise within the specific category, the ? is placed after the category identifier and indicates that the geek has no knowledge about that specific category. For example, a person that has never even heard of Babylon 5, would list their Babylon 5 category as 5?

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.noSuchMethod in an dart:core.Invocation. If geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart:core.NoSuchMethodError.

notRigid.name: notRigid
notRigid.comment:
Original documentation:

@
 For this variable, said trait is not very rigid, may change with time or with individual interaction. For example, Geeks who happen to very much enjoy Star Trek: The Next Generation, but dislike the old 60's series might list themselves as t++@.

refuse.name: refuse
refuse.comment:
Original documentation:

!
 Placed BEFORE the category. Unless stated otherwise, indicates that the person refuses to participate in this category. This is unlike the ? variable as the ? indicates lack of knowledge, while the ! indicates stubborn refusal to participate. For example, !E would be a person that just plain refuses to have anything to do with Emacs, while E? would be a person that doesn't even know what Emacs is.

subValidate.name: subValidate
subValidate.comment:
Lets any implementations of this class execute more specific validations to make sure the builder is set correctly.

This method is invoked from GeekCodeCategory.grade and shouldn't be invoked directly.

Returns a geek_code/geek_code-v312.GeekCodeCategory (or extension of it) if all validations are successful.

geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.subValidate.grade is the grade to apply to this category.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

wannabe.name: wannabe
wannabe.comment:
Takes geek_code/geek_code-v312.UnixGeekCodeCategoryBuilder.wannabe.wannabe's score and sets it as "wannabe" variable for this category.

Original documentation:

>
 For 'wannabe' ratings. Indicating that while the geek is currently at one rating, they are striving to reach another. For example, C++>$ indicating a geek that is currently computer savvy, but wants to someday make money at it.
